title: Palpable Thyroid Nodule with Suspicious Ultrasound
diagnosis_topic: Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma with Nodal Disease
setup_script: “A 45-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a 2 cm thyroid nodule found on routine physical examination. She reports no compressive symptoms. Her thyroid function tests are normal. A neck ultrasound shows a hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe and abnormal cervical lymph nodes. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “She denies prior radiation exposure, has no family history of thyroid cancer, and reports no voice changes or dysphagia.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for physical exam
dynamic_flow.reply: “You palpate a firm 2 cm nodule in the right thyroid lobe. No compressive symptoms are noted. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present on the right.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders additional thyroid labs
dynamic_flow.reply: “Thyroid function tests are within normal limits.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests fine needle aspiration (FNA)
dynamic_flow.reply: “FNA of the thyroid nodule shows Bethesda VI papillary thyroid carcinoma. FNA of a cervical lymph node confirms metastatic carcinoma.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses extent of surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: “Given nodal involvement, what operative approach would you recommend?”
“Given nodal metastases, would this approach be adequate?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection
dynamic_flow.reply: “Preoperative laryngoscopy demonstrates normal vocal cord function. How would you counsel the patient on surgical risks?”
“You explain risks including recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, hypocalcemia, and bleeding. Informed consent is obtained.”
“During surgery, you find gross central neck nodal disease, prompting a formal central compartment dissection. What are your next steps intraoperatively?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked about operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: “Please describe the key technical steps of performing a total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident completes thyroidectomy and dissection
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient is transferred to recovery. Postoperatively, her calcium is 7.1 mg/dL and she reports perioral numbness. How would you manage this?”
“Her symptoms improve with IV calcium and oral supplementation. She is also started on levothyroxine.”
“Final pathology shows papillary thyroid carcinoma, 2 cm, negative margins, 6 of 12 lymph nodes positive for metastases.”
“You refer her to endocrinology for consideration of radioactive iodine therapy.”
“You arrange follow-up with thyroglobulin monitoring and neck ultrasound. What specific symptoms would you educate the patient to monitor for long-term?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of suspicious ultrasound findings and need for FNA.
Decision-making regarding total thyroidectomy versus lobectomy in presence of nodal disease.
Safe operative management protecting recurrent laryngeal nerves and parathyroid glands.
Ability to articulate key technical details of thyroidectomy with nodal dissection.
Postoperative recognition and management of hypocalcemia.
Counseling regarding long-term surveillance and adjuvant therapy.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated solid diagnostic reasoning by identifying suspicious ultrasound features and appropriately ordering FNA. Your operative planning reflected understanding of nodal disease, and you communicated surgical risks effectively. You described the operative steps in a logical and structured manner.Areas for Improvement: Further refinement is needed in outlining technical nuances of the operation and postoperative calcium management. Be more precise in discussing adjuvant therapy options and long-term surveillance.Suggested Reading Topics: - ATA Guidelines on Management of Thyroid Nodules and Differentiated Thyroid Cancer - Surgical Anatomy and Technical Steps of Thyroidectomy with Central Neck Dissection - Management of Post-Thyroidectomy Hypocalcemia and Hypoparathyroidism
